Introduction

An ecosystem is a biotic community and abiotic environment in which the biotic community members live.

Biotic factors

The group of animals, plants, and microbes that interact with each other and their abiotic environment.

Producers

Use light from the Sun to convert carbon dioxide and water into sugar. Release oxygen as a byproduct. Produce organic matter which sustains other species.

Consumers

Feed on producers and other consumers.

Primary consumers

Herbivores - Eat producers

Secondary consumers

Carnivores - eat consumers or Omnivores - eat consumers and producers

Detritus feeders and Decomposers

Organisms which feed on dead plants and animals and return the nutrients to the ecosystem.

Relationships

  • Mutualism - both species benefit
  • Parasitism - one species benefits, the other is harmed
  • Commensalism - one species benefits, the other is unaffected

Food Web

Composed of food chains which make up the different trophic levels of the biomass pyramid.

Abiotic factors

Each species has a range of tolerance for each limiting factor, so those species that fall within their range will populate a certain ecosystem. Each species also has an optimal range for each limiting factor within the range of tolerance in which it experiences to most growth. Outside of the optimal range, each species experiences stress.

Ecotones form when one ecosystem's limiting factors combine with another's giving rise to characteristics of each adjacent ecosystem.

Climate

Climate is a description of the average temperature and rainfall that can be expected each day in a region throughout the entire year.

Climate is determined by weather, so global weather patterns affect the distribution of biomes.

Category: Ecosystem
